article.title: Dictum_of_Kenilworth

template.arg: Award of reconciliation between the king and the rebels of the [[Second Barons' War|Barons' War]].
Restoration of rebels' land, in exchange for fines.

article.paragraph: TheDictum of Kenilworth, issued 31 October 1266, was a pronouncement designed to reconcile the rebels of theSecond Barons' WarBarons' Warwith the royal government ofEngland. After the baronial victory at theBattle of Lewesin 1264,Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of LeicesterSimon de Montforttook control of royal government, but at theBattle of Eveshamthe next year Montfort was killed, and KingHenry III of EnglandHenry IIIrestored to power. A group of rebelsSiege of Kenilworthheld outin the stronghold ofKenilworth Castle, however, and their resistance proved hard to crush.

A siege of the castle was started, but through papal intervention King Henry later entered on a more conciliatory path. A commission was appointed to draw up an arrangement that would be acceptable to both sides. The resulting Dictum of Kenilworth offered the rebels the right to buy back forfeited estates, at prices depending on their level of involvement in the rebellion. After initial resistance, the terms were eventually accepted. By the summer of 1267, the country was pacified, and this spirit of reconciliation would last until the 1290s. The Dictum of Kenilworth was later incorporated into theStatute of Marlborough.
article.heading: Background
article.paragraph: At theBattle of Lewesin 1264, the rebellious barons, led bySimon de Montfort, 6th Earl of LeicesterSimon de Montfort, had defeated the royal army and taken KingHenry III of EnglandHenry IIIcaptive.Prestwich (1988), pp. 45–6.For the next year, the reins of government were in Montfort's hands, but his support soon began to crumble.Prestwich (2005), pp. 115–6On 4 August 1265 Montfort faced an army led by Prince Edward (the later KingEdward I of EnglandEdward I) and the powerfulGilbert de Clare, 6th Earl of Hertfordearl of Gloucester, who had recently defected to the royalist side, at theBattle of Evesham.Maddicott (1994), pp. 327–9.The battle resulted in a complete royal victory; Montfort was killed, and KingHenry III of EnglandHenry IIIwas restored to full power.Prestwich (2005), pp. 116–7.

Part of the rebellious forces held out, however, and their stronghold was the virtually impregnableKenilworth Castle.Prestwich (1988), pp. 52–3.In the summer of 1266, a siege of the castle was initiated, but the effort proved futile.Powicke (1947), pp. 531–2.There were rumours that Montfort's sonSimon VI de MontfortSimonwas planning an invasion of England fromNormandy, and this was the hope that the rebels hung on to.Powicke (1953), p. 208.It was in this situation that the papal legatePope Adrian VOttobuono Fieschiexerted his influence, to make the king pursue a more conciliatory policy.Ottobuono later became pope, asPope Adrian VAdrian V; Powicke (1947), pp. 526–8.In August, the king summoned a parliament atKenilworth, where the siege was ongoing.Powicke (1947), p. 532.He commissioned a number of earls, barons and bishops to draft a treaty of reconciliation.Powicke (1953), p. 209.
article.heading: The Dictum of Kenilworth
article.paragraph: The commission was created by parliament appointing three bishops and three barons, who then selected one more bishop, two earls, and three more barons.The final committee consisted of the bishops ofBishop of ExeterExeter,Bishop of Bath and WellsBath and Wells,Bishop of WorcesterWorcesterandBishop of St. David'sSt. David's, the earls ofEarl of GloucesterGloucesterandEarl of HerefordHereford, and six barons.Walter Branscombe,List of bishops of ExeterBishop of Exeter,Walter Giffard,List of Bishops of Bath and Wells and precursor officesBishop of Bath and Wells,Nicholas of Ely,List of bishops of WorcesterBishop of Worcester,Richard Carew (bishop)Richard Carew,Bishop of St. David's,Gilbert de Clare, 7th Earl of HertfordGilbert de Clare, Earl of Hertford,Humphrey de Bohun, 2nd Earl of HerefordHumphrey de Bohun, Earl of Hereford,Philip Basset,John I de BalliolJohn Balliol,Robert Walerand,Alan la Zouche (12051270)Alan la Zouche,Roger de SomeryandWarin Basingbourne; Rothwell (1975), p. 380.This committee was given until All Saints Day (1 November) to come up with provisions for a settlement.Powicke (1947), pp. 532–3.The result, known as the DictumA "dictum" in this context is anedictorwikt:awardaward, i.e. a legal ruling by an authority;cite webhttp://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/50063594dictum, ''n.''[[Oxford Dictionary of English]]2008-10-28yesof Kenilworth, was made public on 31 October 1266."on the day before theCalendskalendsof November"; Rothwell (1975), p. 380.

The primary point of the Dictum was the re-establishment of royal authority.Article 1 (the numbers refer to the articles of the Dictum as they appear in Rothwell (1975), pp. 380–4).TheProvisions of Oxford, that had been forced on the king, were repudiated, and it was made clear that the appointment of ministers was entirely aRoyal Prerogativeroyal prerogative.Article 7.King Henry in turn reconfirmedMagna Cartaand theCharter of the Forest.Article 3.Measures were taken to renounce the increasing veneration of the fallen Simon de Montfort,Article 8.whom some were already starting to consider a martyr and a possible saint.Maddicott (1994), pp. 346–7.

The rebels had previously been completely disinherited, and their land taken into the king's hands.Powicke (1953), p. 204.The Dictum instead extended a pardon,Article 5.and restored land to their previous owners, contingent on payment of certain penalties that were proportional to the level of involvement in the rebellion. It was traditional to value land at ten times its annual yield,Powicke (1947), p. 536.and most of the rebels were subsequently fined at half of this amount: five times the annual yield of their lands.Article 12.

Robert de Ferrers, 6th Earl of DerbyRobert Ferrers, Earl of Derby, was singled out in particular for his central involvement in the rebellion, and for him the multiple was seven rather than five.Article 14.The same was the case forHenry de Hastings, 1st Baron HastingsHenry de Hastings, who was the commander of Kenilworth Castle.Article 17.Those who had not taken part in the fighting themselves, but had incited others to rise up against the king, were fined at two year's value,Article 26.while those who had been compelled to fight, or played only a minor part, had to pay one year's value of their land.Article 27.The proceedings from the fines were awarded to royal supporters,Article 22.some of whom had already been awarded parts of the rebels' land, and now had to give it back.Powicke (1947), p. 537.
article.heading: Aftermath
article.paragraph: Hostilities did not end with the publication of the Dictum.Powicke (1947), p. 538.The garrison at Kenilworth refused to accept the terms given, and held out until 14 December, when deprivation forced them to surrender.Powicke (1947), p. 539.In April 1267, the earl of Gloucesterspaced ndashwho had been central both to the royal victory at Evesham and to the drafting of the Dictumspaced ndashturned against the king. He occupied the city ofLondon, and set himself up as the champion of the disinherited.Prestwich (1988), pp. 58–9.After negotiations involving both Edward and Ottobuono, Gloucester relented, and by June a settlement was reached.Prestwich (1988), p. 9.Gloucester had forced a change to the conditions of the Dictum, whereby the disinherited were allowed to recover their lands before they had paid their fines rather than after; an arrangement that made repayment much easier.Prestwich (2005), p. 121.In the summer of that year, Prince Edward moved at theIsle of Ely, where the last of the rebels still held out, and forced them into submission under terms favourable to the rebels.Prestwich (1988), p. 59.

In November 1267, parliament met atMarlborough, WiltshireMarlborough.Ridgeway (2004).Some authorities refer to the meeting as a great council rather than a parliament; Powicke (1953), p. 209.Here an important provision was issued that would become known to history as theStatute of Marlborough.Powicke (1947), p. 543.This statute incorporated the clauses of the Dictum of Kenilworth that dealt with the restoration of royal power, and reconciliation between the loyalists and the rebels.Powicke (1947), p. 547.The Statute of Marlborough became a basis for royal government, and the relationship between the king and his subjects, and as such the Dictum lived on in English constitutional history.Powicke (1947), pp. 547–9.

The spirit of peace and reconciliation established by the Dictum of Kenilworth lasted for the remainder of Henry III's reign and into the 1290s.In 1270, Prince Edward left the country to go onNinth Crusadecrusadein theHoly Land.Prestwich (1988), p. 73.When his father died in 1272, Edward felt in a safe enough position to wait until 1274 before returning home to claim the throne.Prestwich (2005), pp. 122–3.
